title: Introduction to {evsim}
text: function evsim package necessary simulate new EV sessions function simulate_sessions, returns tibble EV charging sessions. required input arguments run function : EV model (object class evmodel) Number daily sessions time-cycle model User profiles distribution (ratio every user profile) specific charging power (required) Charging power distribution (ratio every different charging rate) Dates simulate

title: Introduction to {evsim}
text: Package evsim provides EV model example, model created California ACN data California article evprof documentation. model can accessed loading evsim package following function: Let’s take look information print function shows evmodel object: 2 different time-cycles case (Workdays Weekends), one corresponding user profiles. time, user profile time-cycle modeled two different models: Connection Models: combination multiple Gaussian distributions two variables (Connection Start Time Connection Duration) Energy Models: combination multiple Gaussian distributions one variable (Energy) Moreover, User profile corresponding ratio total number daily sessions. case, Workday time-cycle half charging sessions Vist users half Worktime users, Weekend time-cycle sessions Visit users.
code: ev_model <- evsim::california_ev_model print(ev_model) ## EV sessions model of class "evmodel", created on 2023-09-14  ## Timezone of the model: America/Los_Angeles  ## The Gaussian Mixture Models of EV user profiles are built in: ##   - Connection Models: logarithmic scale ##   - Energy Models: logarithmic scale ##  ## Model composed by 2 time-cycles: ##   1. Workday: ##      Months = 1-12, Week days = 1-2 ##      User profiles = Visit, Worktime ##   2. Weekend: ##      Months = 1-12, Week days = 6-7 ##      User profiles = Visit workday_models <- ev_model$models$user_profiles[[1]] workday_models ## # A tibble: 2 × 4 ##   profile  ratio connection_models energy_models    ##   <chr>    <dbl> <list>            <list>           ## 1 Visit    0.464 <tibble [3 × 3]>  <tibble [1 × 2]> ## 2 Worktime 0.536 <tibble [3 × 3]>  <tibble [1 × 2]> weekend_models <- ev_model$models$user_profiles[[2]] weekend_models ## # A tibble: 1 × 4 ##   profile ratio connection_models energy_models    ##   <chr>   <int> <list>            <list>           ## 1 Visit       1 <tibble [2 × 3]>  <tibble [1 × 2]>

title: Introduction to {evsim}
text: set number sessions per day function simulate_sessions() function need pass tibble variables time_cycle (names corresponding evmodel$models$time_cycle) n_sessions (number daily sessions per day time-cycle model). example:
code: sessions_day <- tibble(   time_cycle = ev_model$models$time_cycle,   n_sessions = c(150, 50) ) sessions_day ## # A tibble: 2 × 2 ##   time_cycle n_sessions ##   <chr>           <dbl> ## 1 Workday           150 ## 2 Weekend            50

title: Introduction to {evsim}
text: “EV model” section seen inside ev_model object already default distribution user profiles, one corresponding ratio. ratio values obtained clustering process done evprof package represent presence every user profile total number sessions clustered. However, may want simulate different scenarios use cases ratios differ current ones. example, simulate EV demand industrial area interesting prioritize presence Worktime sessions Visit sessions. can done setting new user profiles’ distribution tibble, must contain variables time_cycle, profile ratio. default values variables, included within model, can obtained function get_user_profiles_distribution. mandatory time-cycles user profiles appear user_profiles tibble. rule simple: time cycles user profiles appearing user_profiles tibble simulated. Moreover, can specify charging power concrete user profile. useful scenarios type vehicle (e.g. truck) charges different rate rest vehicles. can done column power user_profiles tibble, setting power values kW. user profiles without specific power value simulated random charging power obtained according charging power distribution (see next section). example, let’s say want simulate Workday distribution 80% sessions Worktime 20% sessions Visit, considering Worktime sessions charge three-phase AC vehicles 16A connection (11 kW). user_profiles tibble following one:
code: user_profiles <- tibble(   time_cycle = c('Workday', 'Workday', 'Weekend'),   profile = c('Visit', 'Worktime', 'Visit'),   ratio = c(0.2, 0.8, 1),   power = c(NA, 11, NA) )  user_profiles ## # A tibble: 3 × 4 ##   time_cycle profile  ratio power ##   <chr>      <chr>    <dbl> <dbl> ## 1 Workday    Visit      0.2    NA ## 2 Workday    Worktime   0.8    11 ## 3 Weekend    Visit      1      NA

title: Introduction to {evsim}
text: charging power variable modeled Gaussian Mixture Models (GMM) like connection variables energy. However, energy GMM can built charging power separately (see User profiles modelling evprof website), since general energy charged depends charging power (higher charging power higher energy demand). purpose letting charging power GMM variable depends EV model charging point, may change scenarios. example, may want simulate scenario vehicles three-phase connection (11 kW) instead current scenario still lot vehicles charging single phase (3.7 kW). Therefore, convenient set option simulate specific distribution charging powers simulated EV fleet. done charging_powers tibble variables power ratio. public charging infrastructure common standard power rates : 3.7 kW AC (single-phase 16A) 7.3 kW AC (two-phase 16A) 11 kW AC (three-phase 16A) energy GMM built according charging power, recommended power values charging_powers tibble match original charging power values. can found inside models. example ev_model issue, see Workday energy models Visit user profile built charging power since charging_rate column shows Unknown value: case, energy GMM used power values. However, energy models 3.7 kW 11 kW separately, want simulate 22 kW sessions, models used 22 kW sessions 11 kW models since best approximate solution. follow example, can set following charging power distribution: complements variable power user_profiles tibble (see previous section). charging_powers tibble used assign charging power user profiles’ sessions without power specified user_profiles.
code: workday_models$energy_models[[1]] # Visit profile energy models ## # A tibble: 1 × 2 ##   charging_rate energy_models    ##   <chr>         <list>           ## 1 Unknown       <tibble [6 × 3]> charging_powers <- tibble(   power = c(3.7, 7.3, 11),   ratio = c(0.2, 0.4, 0.4) ) charging_powers ## # A tibble: 3 × 2 ##   power ratio ##   <dbl> <dbl> ## 1   3.7   0.2 ## 2   7.3   0.4 ## 3  11     0.4

title: Introduction to {evsim}
text: function simulate_sessions() automatically selects time-cycle fits specific date. pass vector dates want simulate. example: Another datetime argument simulation function needs time resolution datetime variables sessions (connection start, connection end, charging end, …). example set time resolution 15 minutes, argument resolution = 15.

title: Introduction to {evsim}
text: now required data ready simulate new sessions: obtained total 700 sessions 7 simulation dates (.e. 100 sessions/day), session corresponding specific charging profile. can notice datetime variables resolution 15 minutes according configuration, energy required corresponds product Power ChargingHours. can check number sessions power rate corresponds configuration:
code: sessions_estimated <- simulate_sessions(   ev_model,   sessions_day,    user_profiles,   charging_powers,   dates_sim,   resolution = 15 )  head(sessions_estimated) ## # A tibble: 6 × 11 ##   Session Timecycle Profile  ConnectionStartDateTime ConnectionEndDateTime ##   <chr>   <chr>     <chr>    <dttm>                  <dttm>                ## 1 S1      Workday   Worktime 2019-09-10 05:00:00     2019-09-10 13:56:00   ## 2 S2      Workday   Worktime 2019-09-10 05:15:00     2019-09-10 14:52:00   ## 3 S3      Workday   Worktime 2019-09-10 05:15:00     2019-09-10 16:22:00   ## 4 S4      Workday   Worktime 2019-09-10 05:30:00     2019-09-10 15:37:00   ## 5 S5      Workday   Worktime 2019-09-10 05:30:00     2019-09-10 16:16:00   ## 6 S6      Workday   Worktime 2019-09-10 05:30:00     2019-09-10 14:11:00   ## # ℹ 6 more variables: ChargingStartDateTime <dttm>, ChargingEndDateTime <dttm>, ## #   Power <dbl>, Energy <dbl>, ConnectionHours <dbl>, ChargingHours <dbl> sessions_estimated %>%    group_by(Profile, Power) %>%    summarise(n = n()) %>%    mutate(pct = n/sum(n)*100) ## # A tibble: 4 × 4 ## # Groups:   Profile [2] ##   Profile  Power     n   pct ##   <chr>    <dbl> <int> <dbl> ## 1 Visit      3.7    44    20 ## 2 Visit      7.3    88    40 ## 3 Visit     11      88    40 ## 4 Worktime  11     480   100

title: Introduction to {evsim}
text: Finally, can calculate estimated demand function get_demand(). function accepts optional argument, dttm_seq, datetime sequence time-series demand data frame returned function. set datetime sequence first last date resolution 15 minutes timezone original model (using lubridate::with_tz() function): plot estimated demand (making use {dygraphs} package custom package {dutils}):
code: dttm_seq <- seq.POSIXt(   from = as.POSIXct('2019-09-10'),    to = as.POSIXct('2019-09-16'),    by = '15 min' ) %>%    lubridate::with_tz(     ev_model$metadata$tzone   ) estimated_demand <- sessions_estimated %>%    get_demand(dttm_seq)

title: Authors and Citation
text: Marc Cañigueral. Author, maintainer.

title: Authors and Citation
text: Cañigueral M (2023). evsim: Electric Vehicle Charging Sessions Simulation. R package version 1.2.0, https://github.com/mcanigueral/evsim/.
code: @Manual{,   title = {evsim: Electric Vehicle Charging Sessions Simulation},   author = {Marc Cañigueral},   year = {2023},   note = {R package version 1.2.0},   url = {https://github.com/mcanigueral/evsim/}, }

title: Electric Vehicle Charging Sessions Simulation
text: {evsim} part suite packages analyse, model simulate charging behavior electric vehicle users: {evprof}: Electric Vehicle PROFiling {evsim}: Electric Vehicle SIMulation {evsim} package provides functions : Simulating new EV sessions based Gaussian Mixture Models created package {evprof} Calculating power demand data set EV sessions specific time resolution Calculating occupancy (number vehicles connected) specific time resolution Including EV model inputs Shiny Dashboard (Shiny module provided)

title: Electric Vehicle Charging Sessions Simulation
text: data set EV charging sessions already built EV model evprof, best place start Get started chapter package website.

title: Electric Vehicle Charging Sessions Simulation
text: Since package yet CRAN, can install development version evsim GitHub:

title: Electric Vehicle Charging Sessions Simulation
text: encounter clear bug, please open issue minimal reproducible example GitHub. questions discussion, please send mail marc.canigueral@udg.edu. technical details, can read following academic articles methodology used paper: Electric vehicle user profiles aggregated flexibility planning. IEEE PES Innovative Smart Grid Technologies Europe (ISGT Europe). IEEE, Oct. 18, 2021. DOI: 10.1109/isgteurope52324.2021.9639931. Flexibility management electric vehicles based user profiles: Arnhem case study. International Journal Electrical Power Energy Systems, vol. 133. Elsevier BV, p. 107195, Dec. 2021. DOI: 10.1016/j.ijepes.2021.107195. Potential benefits scheduling electric vehicle sessions limiting charging power. CIRED Porto Workshop 2022: E-mobility power distribution systems. Institution Engineering Technology, 2022. DOI: 10.1049/icp.2022.0744.

title: Electric Vehicle Charging Sessions Simulation
text: work developed PhD program eXiT research group University Girona (Catalonia) collaboration Resourcefully, energy transition consulting company based Amsterdam, Netherlands.

what: Calculate connection and charging times according to energy, power and time resolution — adapt_charging_features
title: Calculate connection and charging times according to energy, power and time resolution — adapt_charging_features
text: sessions' Power must higher 0, avoid NaN values dividing zero.

title: Calculate connection and charging times according to energy, power and time resolution — adapt_charging_features
Calculate connection and charging times according to energy, power and time resolution — adapt_charging_features
text: sessions tibble, sessions data set standard format marked {evprof} package (see article) time_resolution integer, time resolution (minutes) sessions' datetime variables power_resolution numeric, power resolution (kW) sessions' power

title: Calculate connection and charging times according to energy, power and time resolution — adapt_charging_features
text: tibble

title: Calculate connection and charging times according to energy, power and time resolution — adapt_charging_features
text: ConnectionStartDateTime first aligned desired time resolution, ConnectionEndDateTime calculated according ConnectionHours. ChargingHours recalculated values Energy Power, limited ConnectionHours. Finally, charging times also calculated.

what: Assign charging station to charging sessions data set — add_charging_infrastructure
title: Assign charging station to charging sessions data set — add_charging_infrastructure
text: Variable ChargingStation Socketwill assigned sessions tibble name pattern : names_prefix + "CHS" + number

title: Assign charging station to charging sessions data set — add_charging_infrastructure
code: add_charging_infrastructure(   sessions,   resolution = 15,   min_stations = 0,   names_prefix = NULL,   connections_th = 10 )

title: Assign charging station to charging sessions data set — add_charging_infrastructure
text: sessions tibble, sessions data set standard format marked {evprof} package (see article) resolution integer, time resolution minutes min_stations integer, minimum number charging stations consider names_prefix character, prefix charging station names (optional) connections_th integer, minimum percentage time intervals certain number vehicles connected. used avoid sizing charging infrastructure host example 100 vehicles 5% time 80 vehicles connected. , setting connections_th = 5 ensure -size charging infrastructure. recommended find value multiple iterations.

title: Get the EV model object of class evmodel — get_ev_model
code: get_ev_model(   names,   months_lst = list(1:12, 1:12),   wdays_lst = list(1:5, 6:7),   connection_GMM,   energy_GMM,   connection_log,   energy_log,   data_tz )

title: Get the EV model object of class evmodel — get_ev_model
text: names character vector given names time-cycle model months_lst list integer vectors corresponding months year time-cycle model wdays_lst list integer vectors corresponding days week model (week start = 1) connection_GMM list different connection bivariate GMM obtained get_connection_models_from_parameters energy_GMM list different energy univariate GMM obtained get_energy_models_from_parameters connection_log logical, true connection models logarithmic transformations energy_log logical, true energy models logarithmic transformations data_tz character, time zone original data (necessary properly simulate new sessions)

title: Get the EV model object of class evmodel — get_ev_model
text: object class evmodel

title: Get the EV model object of class evmodel — get_ev_model
code: # For workdays time cycle workdays_parameters <- dplyr::tibble(   profile = c("Worktime", "Visit"),   ratio = c(80, 20),   start_mean = c(9, 11),   start_sd = c(1, 4),   duration_mean = c(8, 4),   duration_sd = c(0.5, 2),   energy_mean = c(15, 6),   energy_sd = c(4, 3) )  # For weekends time cycle weekends_parameters <- dplyr::tibble(   profile = "Visit",   ratio = 100,   start_mean = 12,   start_sd = 4,   duration_mean = 3,   duration_sd = 2,   energy_mean = 4,   energy_sd = 4 )   # Get the whole model ev_model <- get_ev_model(   names = c("Workdays", "Weekends"),   months_lst = list(1:12, 1:12),   wdays_lst = list(1:5, 6:7),   connection_GMM = purrr::map(     list(Workdays = workdays_parameters, Weekends = weekends_parameters),     ~ get_connection_models_from_parameters(.x)   ),   energy_GMM = purrr::map(     list(Workdays = workdays_parameters, Weekends = weekends_parameters),     ~ get_energy_models_from_parameters(.x)   ),   connection_log = FALSE,   energy_log = FALSE,   data_tz = "Europe/Amsterdam" )

title: evsim 1.2.0
text: Improved functions calculating demand occupancy (now parallel computing) Included example data (evsim::california_ev_sessions evsim::california_ev_sessions_profiles). Included functions create model Gaussian Mixture Models parameters.

title: evsim 1.1.0
text: Added read_ev_model function read EV model JSON file generated package evprof

title: evsim 1.0.0
text: Bug fix evmodel class printing function Adding California’s EV model example evmodel (evsim::california_ev_model). Function “simulate_sessions” now requires “user_profiles” parameter ratio every user profile optional specific power. Add function “get_user_profiles_distribution” facilitate creation newly requested parameter “user_profiles” function “simulate_sessions” Remove function update_profiles_ratios favour prepare_models. new function used inside simulate_sessions function using sessions_day user_profiles parameters modify evmodel input.

title: evsim 0.1.0
text: First release
